channel.title: Interesting links from Better Next Week by Olivia Wang.
channel.description: Your weekly dose of productivity, coding, and self-improvement inspiration

item.title: Reading Better Retaining and Applying What You Read
item.description: Reading techniques. The blank sheet method seems to be a good way to take notes. I'll try it sometime.
item.guid: https://oliwang.github.io/Sharing/2023-01-06 Reading Better Retaining and Applying What You Read/

item.title: Set In Obsidian Plugin
item.description: Plugin that allows time planning in obsidian. Looks promising. I'll try it when 1.1.x is released.
item.content: Plugin that allows time planning in obsidian. Looks promising. I'll try it when 1.1.x is released.

item.title: KAPWING-OlineVideoConverter
item.description: Convert any video to MP3, GIF, MP4, or JPEG online. You can also import a youtube video with url, edit it and export as a gif.
item.content: Convert any video to MP3, GIF, MP4, or JPEG online. You can also import a youtube video with url, edit it and export as a gif.

item.title: The Intermediate Plateau What Causes It How Can We Move Beyond It
item.description: The intermediate plateau is a frustrating stage of learning where progress slows and it is difficult to tell if effort is paying off. Three theories for why we get stuck in this stage are discussed: knowledge grows exponentially with the level of expertise, progress comes to rely more on unlearning than new learning, and creative problem-solving overtakes (and is harder than!) imitating others. To move beyond intermediacy, one must invest exponential effort, practice unlearning, and seek expert mentorship.
item.guid: https://oliwang.github.io/Sharing/2023-01-05 The Intermediate Plateau What Causes It How Can We Move Beyond It/
item.content: The intermediate plateau is a frustrating stage of learning where progress slows and it is difficult to tell if effort is paying off. Three theories for why we get stuck in this stage are discussed: knowledge grows exponentially with the level of expertise, progress comes to rely more on unlearning than new learning, and creative problem-solving overtakes (and is harder than!) imitating others. To move beyond intermediacy, one must invest exponential effort, practice unlearning, and seek expert mentorship.
